text: Eerhm.. I All of a sudden received a the certifcate anyways? Don't know if anyone in here looked at my submission again? But thank you to whoever might have done that for me! :slightly_smiling_face: :heart:

<@UTKQ78G4A> I have to apologize. I'm not actually sure what happened with your practicum. I checked it out and it looks great and you should be all set. I'm pretty sure for some reason I couldn't find your form submission so I looked up your email and looked for your work inside the portal associated with it. Unfortunately I get quite a few submissions where people just mash the buttons and don't actually do the work.
Yes, I manually graded it a few moments ago
Thank you so much <@U3PKJ8EQL>! I was so confused and upset when I didn't pass :sweat_smile:

Haha. I'm sure. I apologize. I send detailed emails to folks who fail, but only if they made an attempt. Someday we'll have a more elegant system for these things so I don't have two competing forms to sift through. I'm just glad you reached out.

I have set up a local development environment and I have successfully set it up to sync between my machine and my development sandbox to start creating a theme. I am using the boilerplate. I followed all the steps here: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/tutorials/getting-started>. HOWEVER, when I test out changing the body color to red (as suggested by this guide), the color of the text on the homepage preview does not change to red. I noticed in Chrome development tools that the style of color is being overridden. This behavior is not indicated by the quick start guide. How can I see the changes I am making in the CSS without it being overridden?

Thanks for pointing this out <@UFAANRW07>! We will make sure and update the quick start to have you update a selector which will actually impact the styling of the page :faceplam:.

If you would like, you could edit the same CSS, but just in the `theme-overrides.css` file of the boilerplate to see things actually impacting your page.
Could I theoretically remove the overrides.css file while I develop and bring it back later?

Up to you depending on how you want to explore and play around!  `theme-overrides.css` is important to make sure all of the theme settings that are part of the boilerplate actually work.

This file is a new addition to the boilerplate, so we will update step 6 to make sure this conflict does not happen.
